summary.title: PFC Burn Multitrauma
summary.description: In this scenario, a soldier was in transport via humvee when it drove over a mine. The patient suffered several burns accounting for approximately one third of his body surface area, mild lacerations, and critical airway trauma. At the start of the scenario, the patient has just arrived in a temporary bunker that has been set up for medical care as best it could given the limited supplies. Basic medical tools, mild pain management substances, and first aid equipment is available. Another solider is available to step in as the medical assistant; however, all decisions must be made by the participating caretaker. No medical treatment has been given at this point and a helicopter will not be available to evacuate the patient for at least several hours. Thus, the patient needs to be stabilized and kept alive until then.
summary.keywords: Burn, Airway Trauma, Hemorrhage, Multitrauma, First Degree, Second Degree
summary.limitations: Burn severity is tracked by percent surface area as opposed to tissue depth.

equipment.name: Antibiotics
equipment.summary: Antimicrobial substance active against bacteria, used in the treatment and prevention of bacterial infections.
equipment.description: This medication usually comes in the form of a pill. There are different types of antibiotics for different applications.

equipment.name: Blanket
equipment.summary: Low-weight, low-bulk blanket made of heat-reflective thin plastic sheeting.
equipment.description: Also referred to as mylar, these are commonly used to prevent heat loss from a human body.

equipment.name: Blood Bag [Type O]
equipment.summary: summary for equipment 31.
equipment.description: This bag represents one unit of Type O blood which is roughly 450 ml in volume.

equipment.name: Blood Collection Bag
equipment.summary: Clear plastic bag used to collect and store blood.
equipment.description: Bags are usually 500 mL in volume (referred to as one unit). Blood type is dependent on antigen presence (A/B) or absence (O) in addition to the presence or absence of Rh factor (+/-).

equipment.name: Blood Transfusion Kit
equipment.summary: Kit used for in field blood transfusion.
equipment.description: Designed for field application, a transfusion kit contains supplies necessary to collect and transfuse fresh whole blood (FWB). The kit typically contains everything from safety supplies and equipment (gloves, blood type test kits, and swabsticks) to collection materials (tubing, needles, collection bag, etc.). Additionally, two sets of most safety materials are supplied to prevent multiple uses on both donor and recipient (i.e. two needles).

equipment.name: Burn Ointments
equipment.summary: Neosporin Burn Relief & First-Aid Antibiotic Ointment, .5 OZ
equipment.description: NEOSPORIN + Burn Relief Dual Action Ointment is an antibiotic ointment that provides infection protection and helps soothe minor burn pain. Formulated for first aid wound treatment, it contains bacitracin zinc, neomycin sulfate, and polymyxin B sulfate for antibiotic care of minor burns and wounds. The topical analgesic ointment is also formulated with pramoxine hydrochloride to help soothe and reduce burn pain for maximum-strength relief. From the #1 doctor-recommended brand, this antibiotic and pain relief ointment provides maximum strength relief without any sting forburn treatment, including cooking burns. Neosporin + Burn Relief Dual Action Ointment is a wound care essential to include in any burn care first-aid kit.

equipment.name: Catheter Supplies
equipment.summary: Catheters and the products that are used to insert or remove a catheter, and maintain catheter function.

equipment.name: Chest Tube
equipment.summary: A chest tube is a hollow, flexible tube placed into the chest.
equipment.description: Acts as a drain. Chest tubes drain blood, fluid, or air from around your lungs, heart, or esophagus. The tube around your lung is placed between your ribs and into the space between the inner lining and the outer lining of your chest cavity

equipment.name: Energy Gel
equipment.summary: Carbohydrate gel used to provide energy and promote recovery.

equipment.name: Epinephrine
equipment.summary: A chemical that narrows blood vessels and opens airways in the lungs.
equipment.description: Also referred to as adrenaline, this drug is used to treat life-threatening allergic reactions. Epinephrine acts quickly and works to improve breathing, stimulate the heart, raise a dropping blood pressure, reverse hives, and reduce swelling.

equipment.name: Fentanyl
equipment.summary: A synthetic opioid pain reliever, approved for treating severe pain.
equipment.description: Fentanyl is a prescription drug that is also made and used illegally. Like morphine, it is a medicine that is typically used to treat patients with severe pain, especially after surgery. It is also sometimes used to treat patients with chronic pain who are physically tolerant to other opioids.

equipment.name: IV Bag
equipment.summary: Bag used to store and deliver fluids to a patient.

equipment.name: IV Pole
equipment.summary: The pole use to hang IV bags on.
equipment.description: It provides patient mobility to move around a facility while keeping IV lines in.

equipment.name: Ketamine
equipment.summary: A dissociative anesthetic used pain relief.
equipment.description: Ketamine can provide pain relief and short-term memory loss (for example, amnesia of a medical procedure). In surgery, it is used an induction and maintenance agent for sedation and to provide general anesthesia. It has also been used for pain control in burn therapy, battlefield traumas, and in children who cannot use other anesthetics due to side effects or allergies. At normal doses, it is often preferred as an anesthetic in patients at risk of bronchospasm and respiratory depression.

equipment.name: Midazolam
equipment.summary: A short action sedative used for anesthesia, procedural sedation, trouble sleeping, and severe agitation.
equipment.description: Midazolam injection is used before medical procedures and surgery to cause drowsiness, relieve anxiety, and prevent any memory of the event. It is also sometimes given as part of the anesthesia during surgery to produce a loss of consciousness.

equipment.name: Morphine
equipment.summary: A narcotic pain reliever used to treat moderate to severe pain.
equipment.description: Morphine is an opioid medication used to treat severe chronic pain. It has a high rate of addiction, overdose, and death.

equipment.name: Narcan
equipment.summary: Naloxone, a medication used to block the effects of opioids, commonly used for decreased breathing in opioid overdose.
equipment.description: Naloxone is a medicine that rapidly reverses an opioid overdose. It attaches to opioid receptors and reverses and blocks the effects of other opioids. Naloxone is a safe medicine. It only reverses overdoses in people with opioids in their systems.

equipment.name: Nasal Cannula
equipment.summary: A device used to deliver increased airflow to a patient in need of respiratory help.
equipment.description: Tubing with two prongs that get inserted into a patient's nose, this equipment is attached to an oxygen source and mainly used to control oxygen flow to the patient. The advantages to this delivery method is that is less invasive than other oxygen masks and allows a patient to eat and speak normally.

equipment.name: Needle Decompression Kits
equipment.summary: 14 guage by 3.25 inch needle and catheter
equipment.description: This is a 14 gauge by 3.25 inch needle and catheter for use in the management of combat casualties who present with the signs and symptoms of a tension pneumothorax. This device meets 100% of the requirements for fit, form and function that is listed for NSN 6515-01-541-0635. The hard plastic case protects the needle and catheter from bending or damage and harsh environmental conditions while in your kit.

equipment.name: Oxygen Tank
equipment.summary: A tank of oxygen.
equipment.description: In medicine, an oxygen tank provide controlled and therapeutic oxygen delivery to a patient.

equipment.name: Peripheral IV
equipment.summary: A peripheral intravenous line is a small, short plastic catheter that is placed through the skin into a vein.
equipment.description: A peripheral intravenous line is used to give fluids and/or medications directly into the blood stream.

equipment.name: Splint
equipment.summary: a rigid or flexible device that maintains in position a displaced or injured part.
equipment.description: Mostly used for broken bones, a splint is fastened along a injured length of a person's body in order to limit movement and further trauma.

equipment.name: Syringe
equipment.summary: Simple reciprocating pump using plunger or piston to expel liquid or gas through a hypodermic needle.
equipment.description: In medicine, these can be used to withdraw liquids, such as when cleaning wounds or body cavities, or to inject fluids, as is the case with some drug injections.

equipment.name: Tempus Pro Kit
equipment.summary: Attatchment kit for the vitals sign monitor.
equipment.description: Light enough to carry and small enough to hold in one hand, it allows the vitals monitor to easily be deployed in numerous clinical scenarios. While it does support many attachments to allow for a wide range of measurements, some important parameters the tempus pro kit measures includes pulse rate, impedance respiration, contact temperature, pulse oximetry, and noninvasive blood pressure.

equipment.name: Tourniquet
equipment.summary: A device which applies pressure to a limb or extremity in order to control the flow of blood.
equipment.description: A tourniquet uses compression, typically on a limb, to constrict a vein or artery and limit blood flow as much as possible. This is typically done during hemorrhaging when limiting blood flow to the extremity also limits the blood lost. In a pinch, a cord or tie can be used.

equipment.name: Urine Bottle
equipment.summary: Bag used to catch and store drained urine.

equipment.name: Urine Foley
equipment.summary: Catheter used to drain urine.
equipment.description: A soft plastic or rubber tube that is inserted through the urethra into the bladder. These are typically used when a patient has difficulties urinating on their own.

equipment.name: Vitals Monitor
equipment.summary: A small, lightweight vital signs monitor.
equipment.description: A basic level vitals monitor with many uses depending on available attacthments.

equipment.name: Water
equipment.summary: An inorganic, transparent, tasteless, odorless, and nearly colorless chemical substance.
equipment.description: It is also essential to and the primary component of living organic beings.

equipment.name: Wound Pack
equipment.summary: Non-adherent and absorbent material used to control bleeding of an open wound.
equipment.description: Wound fillers, such as non-adherent gauze, pads, ointments, sponges, and other materials designed to manage exudate.

equipment.name: Wound Wrap
equipment.summary: A strip of fabric used especially to cover, dress, and bind up wounds.
equipment.description: It can also be used to provide pressure to the bleeding.

trauma.description: Airway traumas are life threatening and often occur as a result of blunt and penetrating force to the neck and/or chest. Diagnosis can be challenging due to symptoms and signs that are nonspecific to this trauma type.
Bleeding under the skin due to trauma to the blood capillaries can cause injured tissues. It usually darkens the skin to a black/blue color.

A heat trauma that affects the first layer of skin. Most commonly, it causes redness, pain, and swelling and will heal on its own, though larger burns can be uncomfortable and may require a doctor's opinion.

Hemorrhaging is the release of blood from any blood vessel, either inside or outside of the body. When discussing hemorrhage, it is important to identify both severity (typically as a measure of blood loss rate) and location.
The invasion and growth of bacteria, viruses, yeast, or fungi in the body. Infections can begin at any point in the body and spread, causing fever and other health issues.
External bleeding of the body produced by the tearing of soft body tissue.
An trauma to the body cause by a piercing or penetrating object. Depth and severity can vary.
A burn that affects the epidermis and dermis (lower layers of skin). In addition to the symptoms of a first degree, a second degree burn can also cause blistering.

A tension pneumothorax is when air leaks into the pleural space between the lungs and chest wall. It typically occurs as a result of blunt or penetrating trauma and can be classified as either open or closed.
A burn that goes through the dermis and affects deep skin tissue layers. The result is a white or blackened, charred skin that may lose some feeling.

treatment-plan.description: Antimicrobial substance active against bacteria, used in the treatment and prevention of bacterial infections. This medication usually comes in the form of a pill. There are different types of antibiotics for different applications.
A strip of fabric used especially to cover, dress, and bind up wounds.
Used to help in the prevention and treatment of infections during burn healing, burn ointment kills infectious microorganisms and reduces inflammation.
A chest tube is a hollow, flexible tube placed into the chest. It acts as a drain for blood, fluid, or air from around the heart and lungs.

During treatment of a hazardous burn, an escharotomy is the surgical incision through the eschar into the subcutaneous tissues to allow the extremity to continue to swell without compressing underlying blood vessels.

Fentanyl is a prescription drug that is also made and used illegally. Like morphine, it is a medicine that is typically used to treat patients with severe pain, especially after surgery. It is also sometimes used to treat patients with chronic pain who are physically tolerant to other opioids.
Morphine is an opioid medication used to treat severe chronic pain. It has a high rate of addiction, overdose, and death.

A procedure performed to stabilize deteriorating patients in the life-threatening situation of a tension pneumothorax. The procedure involves inserting a large needle through the chest wall into the pleural cavity to allow air to escape.

When a wound is deep, or when it tunnels under the skin, packing the wound can help it heal. The packing material soaks up any drainage from the wound, which helps the tissues heal from the inside out.
A stitch or row of stitches holding together the edges of a wound or incision. They typically help hold tissue together during healing.

trauma.location: Closed tension pnehumothorax on Right Side

objective.name: 1. Planning for the event or deployment
objective.description: Actively identify evacuation precedence and any life threatening conditions. Planning makes the user aware of injuries and treatment options in order to better determine a course of action to yield the best possible outcome for your patient.

objective.name: 2. Efficiently control pain and side effects
objective.description: Working with pharmaceuticals comes down to knowing both what drugs are available, what their intended effect is, and potential side effects. Certain preexisting conditions can increase or decrease these effects as well, so planning ahead is a must.

objective.name: 3. Monitoring and trending vitals
objective.description: When executing a plan, visual and graphical vital signs markers help determine the success of each step. Noticing deviations in expected changes early allow for more time to correct them and keep your patient safe. Additionally, serial exams and urine output measurements should be used.

objective.name: 4. Set treatment plan based on threat to patient
objective.description: In this scenario there are multiple sources of trauma/injury to the patient. While some may be more life threatening than others, it is your job as the care provider to identify all sources of trauma and determine how and when to address them or their symptoms.

objective.name: 5. Restore breathing to patient
objective.description: Whether assisted or independent, the respiratory capability of the patient is a crucial component of TCCC guidelines. Recognize whether any deficiencies in breathing are due to pathophysiology, obstruction, or something else and control it.

objective.name: 6. Prevent iatrogenesis while providing aggressive nursing care
objective.description: Do not cause further harm to the patient through mismanaged treatment.

assessment.name: Control of the Airway
assessment.description: The patient develops a collapsed lung by tension pneumothroax on the right side with in 1 hour of the simuaton. The occurance of this event is done by a poison distribution
assessment.criteria: The patient must resolve the lung collapse with in the first few minutes of its occurance and resolve it properly by needle decompresison to pass this assessment.

assessment.name: Manage Infection Area
assessment.description: It is important to manage the possibility of infection by wrapping the wounds and applying bandages with ointment to each location. Once this is done antibioitics should be introduced as part of the fluid resuscitation regement.

assessment.name: Pain Managment
assessment.description: Ensure the patient is properly sedated over the treatment while minimizing application of opoid based sedatives to avoid development of chemical dependence.
assessment.criteria: < 50 cc of Morphone delivered over the 48 hour period > 15 cc of Morphine delivered over 48 hour periuod < 12 hours of patient restlessness

role.name: Assistant
role.description:
The medical assistant standing by to assist in any two-person tasks. This character cannot make decisions and is strictly standing by to assist.
Healthy

role.name: Burn Patient
role.description:
The character having suffered from burns and other traumas, thus causing a need for medical attention.
Burn with Airway Trauma

role.name: Caretaker
role.description:
The decision maker in the scenaro tasked with caring for the injured patient.
Healthy

location.name: Base Camp
location.description: Temporary building with plywood sheeting for walls. Setup at basecamp to act as a temporary operating room while the unit is deployed.

scene.name: Temporary Bunker
scene.description: During operation Iraqi Freedom, a group of US military soldiers were stationed in a bunker at an undiscloded location. A soldier was running surveillance via humvee around some nearby rocky terrain when it drove over a mine. The driver got lucky and was thrown out of the vehicle with minor bruising and bleeding. However, the passenger was ended up pinned by the seat during the blast. The initial explosion left an array of burns across approximately one third of the victim's bodyin addition to lacerations and external bleeding. As scrap metal and debris fell, a piece of metal got lodged in the soldier's neck causing significant airwat trauma. The driver managed to get his comrade to the team's nearby safety bunkner, but the victim is in bad shape and the temporary bunker holds limited medical supplies.

event.name: 01 Patient Arrival
event.description: Patient arrived shortly after injuries begain. The learner has been in the process of cleaning the ptient while awaiting feedback from the Tele-medicine team. The patient currently has no fluids being infused and his sedation medicaiton is wearing off.

event.name: 02 Patient Stirs
event.description: Once the learner begins to act the patient will begin to become frustrated due to pain caused by the wounds. Management of the patient is an intiial priority so proper cleaning can be finished.

event.name: 03 Telecommunication Event
event.details: Use Script 1 BURN CARE for this.
event.description: After managing the patients pain the Telemedicine team can be reached.

event.name: 04 Tension Penumothraox Occurance
event.details: Patient develops a Tension Pnenumothorax at 30 minutes in to the simulation.

event.name: 05 Escharotomy
event.details: The learning objectives do not focus on Escharotomy technique. It is ok for this to be a action event with minimal user feedback. Once this is done correctly the severity of the inflmation on the patients physiology should be appropriately reduced.
event.description: The Telemedicine - Team will ask toe learned to perform escaharotomy incessions to releave swelling based on teh TBSA assessment.
